content.raw: I also started down the road of creating a joint position component. Should this be a `std::vector` instead of two separate components?
content.html: I also started down the road of creating a joint position component. Should this be a std::vector instead of two separate components?

content.raw: Yes. Changed in e506713. In the future, it would be nice if we had another mechanism for variable sized components. Using `std::vector` puts the data somewhere else in memory possibly causing cache misses.
content.html: Yes. Changed in e506713. In the future, it would be nice if we had another mechanism for variable sized components. Using std::vector puts the data somewhere else in memory possibly causing cache misses.

For joints, maybe a simple struct with the 2 axes could do the trick?

struct JointPosition
{
  double axis1;
  double axis2;
}

content.raw: There are joint types that support 3\+ degrees of freedom, so this would lock us out of supporting those types.
content.html: There are joint types that support 3+ degrees of freedom, so this would lock us out of supporting those types.

content.raw: I thought `std::vector` guarantees that data within the vector is stored consecutively in memory.
content.html: I thought std::vector guarantees that data within the vector is stored consecutively in memory.

content.raw: I think that the array within the vector is guaranteed to be contiguous, but the array itself may be somewhere else in memory, and each time the vector is expanded a new array is allocated somewhere else.
content.html: I think that the array within the vector is guaranteed to be contiguous, but the array itself may be somewhere else in memory, and each time the vector is expanded a new array is allocated somewhere else.

content.raw:
The expansion problem could be trivially solved by always reserving 6 components, since there aren’t any joint types that support more than 6 degrees of freedom.

But even if we don’t reserve it, it’s very unlikely that the dimensionality of the vector will be expanded often since the number of DOFs in a joint is fixed.
content.html:
The expansion problem could be trivially solved by always reserving 6 components, since there aren’t any joint types that support more than 6 degrees of freedom.

But even if we don’t reserve it, it’s very unlikely that the dimensionality of the vector will be expanded often since the number of DOFs in a joint is fixed.

content.raw:
It does, for a single `JointPosition` in this case. But multiple `JointPosition` components may not be stored adjacent to each other because they belong to different `std::vector` objects.

@chapulina Two questions:

* Are we okay with fixing the number of axes? We do have some joints that have 3 DOF and @mxgrey [mentioned](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/254/acropolis-add-applyjointforce-system/activity#comment-97872127) possible custom joints.
* Do we want to put it on the user to know which axes are valid based on the joint type?
content.html:
It does, for a single JointPosition in this case. But multiple JointPosition components may not be stored adjacent to each other because they belong to different std::vector objects.

@chapulina Two questions:

  • Are we okay with fixing the number of axes? We do have some joints that have 3 DOF and @mxgrey mentioned possible custom joints.
  • Do we want to put it on the user to know which axes are valid based on the joint type?

content.raw:
> Are we okay with fixing the number of axes?

That's already fixed on SDF.  Gazebo-classic supports ball joints, which have 3 axes, but it provides no API for interacting with the axes one-by-one. If a time comes when we want to improve support for 3-axes-joints, we could add a new element to the struct and bump the version... Or we can just add it now for future-proofing. Do we want to add up to 6 axes to cover the free-joint case? :thinking:

>  Do we want to put it on the user to know which axes are valid based on the joint type?

I think we should protect against the user trying to access a non-existent axis, but were you thinking of something else?
content.html:
Are we okay with fixing the number of axes?

That's already fixed on SDF. Gazebo-classic supports ball joints, which have 3 axes, but it provides no API for interacting with the axes one-by-one. If a time comes when we want to improve support for 3-axes-joints, we could add a new element to the struct and bump the version... Or we can just add it now for future-proofing. Do we want to add up to 6 axes to cover the free-joint case?

Do we want to put it on the user to know which axes are valid based on the joint type?

I think we should protect against the user trying to access a non-existent axis, but were you thinking of something else?

content.raw:
> That's already fixed on SDF. Gazebo-classic supports ball joints, which have 3 axes, but it provides no API for interacting with the axes one-by-one.

It would be nice to support at least 3 DOF joints. Even if they are not controlled, knowing the joint positions might be useful.

> I think we should protect against the user trying to access a non-existent axis, but were you thinking of something else?

What I had in mind was if `JointPosition` has, say 3 axes, and its attached to a 1 axis joint. The user of the component must check another component for the joint type before knowing which axes out of the 3 are valid. With the `std::vector` approach, the physics system populates the correct number of joint positions so there is no need to check another component.
content.html:
That's already fixed on SDF. Gazebo-classic supports ball joints, which have 3 axes, but it provides no API for interacting with the axes one-by-one.

It would be nice to support at least 3 DOF joints. Even if they are not controlled, knowing the joint positions might be useful.

I think we should protect against the user trying to access a non-existent axis, but were you thinking of something else?

What I had in mind was if JointPosition has, say 3 axes, and its attached to a 1 axis joint. The user of the component must check another component for the joint type before knowing which axes out of the 3 are valid. With the std::vector approach, the physics system populates the correct number of joint positions so there is no need to check another component.

content.raw:
+1 to 3 axes

Understood your use case. Maybe using a fixed-size array like in your example makes more sense than a struct then?
content.html:
+1 to 3 axes

Understood your use case. Maybe using a fixed-size array like in your example makes more sense than a struct then?

content.raw:
On the topic of memory adjacency. If multiple components of the same type are stored adjacent in memory, then wouldn't the vectors contained in the components also be stored adjacent in memory?

I'm ignoring the PIMP issue.
content.html:
On the topic of memory adjacency. If multiple components of the same type are stored adjacent in memory, then wouldn't the vectors contained in the components also be stored adjacent in memory?

I'm ignoring the PIMP issue.

content.raw: The diagram [here](https://stackoverflow.com/a/52330123/6451468) may help. The vector instance holds a pointer to the array of elements it holds. So in our case, the vector instances should be close to each other, but the data they're holding could be anywhere.
content.html: The diagram here may help. The vector instance holds a pointer to the array of elements it holds. So in our case, the vector instances should be close to each other, but the data they're holding could be anywhere.

content.raw:
Sample code:

* Using `std::vector`: https://repl.it/repls/ModestHilariousKeyboard
* Using a struct or `std::array`: https://repl.it/repls/GlumGiddyPup
content.html:

  • Using std::vector: https://repl.it/repls/ModestHilariousKeyboard
  • Using a struct or std::array: https://repl.it/repls/GlumGiddyPup

content.raw:
If we super care about the performance difference, then I think the proper solution is to use a bounded dynamic array with an upper limit of 6. I doubt there's any meaningful joint type that would have more than 6 degrees of freedom. That would give us all the advantages of `std::array` and `std::vector` at once.

We could probably just grab a header from ROS2 or some other open source project with a permissive license.
content.html:
If we super care about the performance difference, then I think the proper solution is to use a bounded dynamic array with an upper limit of 6. I doubt there's any meaningful joint type that would have more than 6 degrees of freedom. That would give us all the advantages of std::array and std::vector at once.

We could probably just grab a header from ROS2 or some other open source project with a permissive license.

content.raw: I doubt that this would be the biggest performance problem we have right now. I think an `std::array<double, 6>` could be the best compromise atm.
content.html: I doubt that this would be the biggest performance problem we have right now. I think an std::array<double, 6> could be the best compromise atm.

content.raw:
`std::array` would make it very hard for users \(which includes us\) to understand the expected dimension for the component.

If the performance isn't enough of a concern to just copy/paste a bounded dynamic array header into our repo, then I would recommend going with a `std::vector` for the sake of understandability.
content.html:
std::array would make it very hard for users (which includes us) to understand the expected dimension for the component.

If the performance isn't enough of a concern to just copy/paste a bounded dynamic array header into our repo, then I would recommend going with a std::vector for the sake of understandability.

content.raw: Just to add an additional possible option \(not saying that it is the proper one, just making sure that all the options are listed\) if we expect that in most cases the joint size will be 1, and we want to avoid increasing the total`JointPosition` size for avoiding increasing the total memory usage and reducing the memory locality, a possibility is to use a data structure with small vector optimization set to 1, something similar to [\`llvm::SmallVector\`](http://llvm.org/doxygen/classllvm_1_1SmallVector.html) . However, it is difficult to evaluate the effect of these optimizations without any benchmark.
content.html: Just to add an additional possible option (not saying that it is the proper one, just making sure that all the options are listed) if we expect that in most cases the joint size will be 1, and we want to avoid increasing the totalJointPosition size for avoiding increasing the total memory usage and reducing the memory locality, a possibility is to use a data structure with small vector optimization set to 1, something similar to `llvm::SmallVector` . However, it is difficult to evaluate the effect of these optimizations without any benchmark.

content.raw:
I'm in favor of using `std::vector` for now and addressing this later. 

@mxgrey,  can you point me to the bounded dynamic array header if you have one in mind?
content.html:
I'm in favor of using std::vector for now and addressing this later.

@mxgrey, can you point me to the bounded dynamic array header if you have one in mind?

content.raw:
I was going to recommend looking at ROS2's bounded dynamic array, but I discovered that they're using a `std::vector` to implement it.

The only other example I have is the [boost bounded array](https://github.com/boostorg/ublas/blob/782ce1631d8ba5121c5632ac153c6343ffe0ab36/include/boost/numeric/ublas/storage.hpp#L356), but pulling in one boost header usually doesn’t work well. We could probably just draw inspiration from it to write our own simple bounded dynamic array class.
content.html:
I was going to recommend looking at ROS2's bounded dynamic array, but I discovered that they're using a std::vector to implement it.

The only other example I have is the boost bounded array, but pulling in one boost header usually doesn’t work well. We could probably just draw inspiration from it to write our own simple bounded dynamic array class.

content.raw: Ahh, right...I'll stop talking now.
content.html: Ahh, right...I'll stop talking now.

If you use a std::vector for the JointPosition, then this line could become:

          for (int jointI = 0; jointI < jointIt->second->GetDegreesOfFreedom();
               ++jointI)
          { 
            pos->Data()[jointI] = jointIt->second->GetPosition(jointI);
          }

content.raw: There's a [piece of functionality](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/256/acropolis-port-of-liftdragplugin/diff#Lsrc/systems/lift_drag/LiftDrag.ccT348) in the LiftDrag Plugin that uses the joint position, but it's only [activated](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/256/acropolis-port-of-liftdragplugin/diff#Lsrc/systems/lift_drag/LiftDrag.ccT189) if `control_joint_name` is specified in the SDF parameter of the plugin. I was tempted to remove it because it didn't have any tests, but left it in just in case it's needed.
content.html: There's a piece of functionality in the LiftDrag Plugin that uses the joint position, but it's only activated if control_joint_name is specified in the SDF parameter of the plugin. I was tempted to remove it because it didn't have any tests, but left it in just in case it's needed.

content.raw: nit: `0.5 * IGN_PI` could be `IGN_PI_2`
content.html: nit: 0.5 * IGN_PI could be IGN_PI_2

content.raw:
It's unlikely that there'd be an advantage to using `IGN_PI_2` since the compiler will likely compute the value of this expression at compile time anyway.

Personally I'd rather have the explicitness of `0.5 * IGN_PI` than needing to remember what `IGN_PI_2` actually means \(is it `2*pi`? `pi^2`? Oh right, it's `pi/2`\).
content.html:
It's unlikely that there'd be an advantage to using IGN_PI_2 since the compiler will likely compute the value of this expression at compile time anyway.

Personally I'd rather have the explicitness of 0.5 * IGN_PI than needing to remember what IGN_PI_2 actually means (is it 2*pi? pi^2? Oh right, it's pi/2).

yeah, `0.5 * IGN_PI` or more readable

content.raw: this test is a little different than the osrf/gazebo test, which is ok (actually better since the velocity controller here should converge to steady-state faster than the open-loop controller in osrf/gazebo), but one difference is that this only has expectations for 1 timestep, but the osrf/gazebo test uses the last 15 or so timesteps. it shouldn't be too hard to put this expectation in a for loop and iterate over the last few time steps.
content.html: this test is a little different than the osrf/gazebo test, which is ok (actually better since the velocity controller here should converge to steady-state faster than the open-loop controller in osrf/gazebo), but one difference is that this only has expectations for 1 timestep, but the osrf/gazebo test uses the last 15 or so timesteps. it shouldn't be too hard to put this expectation in a for loop and iterate over the last few time steps.

content.raw: I started working on this and I found out that the test was broken in that the `expVertForce` and `vertForce` were both zero. I made changes in e18e841 to fix that along with your suggestions. I also created another `Relay` system to record wrenches in the PreUpdate because I realized that in the WindEffect PR (PR #273), `ExternalWorldWrenchCmd` is reset to zero by Physics in the Update step.
content.html: I started working on this and I found out that the test was broken in that the expVertForce and vertForce were both zero. I made changes in e18e841 to fix that along with your suggestions. I also created another Relay system to record wrenches in the PreUpdate because I realized that in the WindEffect PR (PR #273), ExternalWorldWrenchCmd is reset to zero by Physics in the Update step.
